indicators.name: Women who believe a wife is justified refusing sex with her husband if she has recently given birth (%)
indicators.description: Percentage of women aged 15-49 who believe that a wife is justified in refusing to have sex with her husband if she has recently given birth.

indicators.name: Women who believe a wife is justified refusing sex with her husband for none of the reasons (%)
indicators.description: Percentage of women aged 15-49 who believe that a wife is justified in refusing to have sex with her husband for none of the reasons: husband has sexually transmitted disease, husband has sex with other women, recently given birth, tired or not in the mood.

indicators.name: Women who believe a wife is justified refusing sex with her husband for all of the reasons (%)
indicators.description: Percentage of women aged 15-49 who believe that a wife is justified in refusing to have sex with her husband for all of the reasons: husband has sexually transmitted disease, husband has sex with other women, recently given birth, tired or not in the mood.

indicators.name: Women who believe a wife is justified refusing sex with her husband if she knows he has sex with other women (%)
indicators.description: Percentage of women aged 15-49 who believe that a wife is justified in refusing to have sex with her husband if she knows husband has sex with other women.

indicators.name: Women who believe a wife is justified refusing sex with her husband if she is tired or not in the mood (%)
indicators.description: Percentage of women aged 15-49 who believe that a wife is justified in refusing to have sex with her husband if she is tired or not in the mood.

indicators.name: Women who believe a wife is justified refusing sex with her husband if she knows he has sexually transmitted disease (%)
indicators.description: Percentage of women aged 15-49 who believe that a wife is justified in refusing to have sex with her husband if she knows husband has sexually transmitted disease.

indicators.name: Proportion of time spent on unpaid domestic and care work, female (% of 24 hour day)
indicators.description: The average time women spend on household provision of services for own consumption. Data are expressed as a proportion of time in a day. Domestic and care work includes food preparation, dishwashing, cleaning and upkeep of a dwelling, laundry, ironing, gardening, caring for pets, shopping, installation, servicing and repair of personal and household goods, childcare, and care of the sick, elderly or disabled household members, among others.

indicators.name: Proportion of time spent on unpaid domestic and care work, male (% of 24 hour day)
indicators.description: The average time men spend on household provision of services for own consumption.  Data are expressed as a proportion of time in a day. Domestic and care work includes food preparation, dishwashing, cleaning and upkeep of a dwelling, laundry, ironing, gardening, caring for pets, shopping, installation, servicing and repair of personal and household goods, childcare, and care of the sick, elderly or disabled household members, among others.

indicators.name: Proportion of women subjected to physical and/or sexual violence in the last 12 months (% of ever-partnered women ages 15-49)
indicators.description: Proportion of women subjected to physical and/or sexual violence in the last 12 months is the percentage of ever partnered women age 15-49 who are subjected to physical violence, sexual violence or both by a current or former intimate partner in the last 12 months.

indicators.name: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she argues with him (%)
indicators.description: Percentage of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she argues with him.

indicators.name: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she burns the food (%)
indicators.description: Percentage of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she burns the food.

indicators.name: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she goes out without telling him (%)
indicators.description: Percentage of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she goes out without telling him.

indicators.name: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she neglects the children (%)
indicators.description: Percentage of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she neglects the children.

indicators.name: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife (any of five reasons) (%)
indicators.description: Percentage of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner for any of the following five reasons: argues with him; refuses to have sex; burns the food; goes out without telling him; or when she neglects the children.

indicators.name: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she refuses sex with him (%)
indicators.description: Percentage of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she refuses sex with him.

indicators.name: Condom use, population ages 15-24, female (% of females ages 15-24)
indicators.description: Condom use, female is the percentage of the female population ages 15-24 who used a condom at last intercourse in the last 12 months.

indicators.name: Condom use, population ages 15-24, male (% of males ages 15-24)
indicators.description: Condom use, male is the percentage of the male population ages 15-24 who used a condom at last intercourse in the last 12 months.

indicators.name: Women's share of population ages 15+ living with HIV (%)
indicators.description: Prevalence of HIV is the percentage of people who are infected with HIV. Female rate is as a percentage of the total population ages 15+ who are living with HIV.

indicators.name: Mortality rate, female child (per 1,000 female children age one)
indicators.description: Child mortality rate is the probability of dying between the exact ages of one and five, if subject to current age-specific mortality rates. The probability is expressed as a rate per 1,000.

indicators.name: Mortality rate, male child (per 1,000 male children age one)
indicators.description: Child mortality rate is the probability of dying between the exact ages of one and five, if subject to current age-specific mortality rates. The probability is expressed as a rate per 1,000.

indicators.name: Demand for family planning satisfied by any methods (% of married women with demand for family planning)
indicators.description: Demand for family planning satisfied by any methods refers to the percentage of married women ages 15-49 whose need for family planning is satisfied.

indicators.name: Prevalence of HIV, female (% ages 15-24)
indicators.description: Prevalence of HIV, female is the percentage of females who are infected with HIV. Youth rates are as a percentage of the relevant age group.

indicators.name: Prevalence of HIV, male (% ages 15-24)
indicators.description: Prevalence of HIV, male is the percentage of males who are infected with HIV. Youth rates are as a percentage of the relevant age group.

indicators.name: Access to anti-retroviral drugs, female (%)
indicators.description: The percentage of adult females living with HIV who are receiving antiretroviral therapy.

indicators.name: Access to anti-retroviral drugs, male (%)
indicators.description: The percentage of adult males living with HIV who are receiving antiretroviral therapy.

indicators.name: Incidence of HIV, ages 15-49, female (per 1,000 uninfected female population ages 15-49)
indicators.description: Number of new HIV infections among uninfected female populations ages 15-49 expressed per 1,000 uninfected female population ages 15-49 in the year before the period.

indicators.name: Incidence of HIV, ages 15-49, male (per 1,000 uninfected male population ages 15-49)
indicators.description: Number of new HIV infections among uninfected male populations ages 15-49 expressed per 1,000 uninfected male population ages 15-49 in the year before the period.

indicators.name: Incidence of HIV, ages 15-24, female (per 1,000 uninfected female population ages 15-24)
indicators.description: Number of new HIV infections among uninfected male populations ages 15-24 expressed per 1,000 uninfected male population ages 15-24 in the year before the period.

indicators.name: Incidence of HIV, ages 15-24, male (per 1,000 uninfected male population ages 15-24)
indicators.description: Number of new HIV infections among uninfected female populations ages 15-24 expressed per 1,000 uninfected female population ages 15-24 in the year before the period.

indicators.name: Length of paid maternity leave (calendar days)
indicators.description: The indicator refers to leave available only to the mother for the birth of a child to be taken just before, during and immediately after childbirth.

indicators.name: Paid leave of at least 14 weeks available to mothers (1=yes; 0=no)
indicators.description: The indicator measures  whether women are legally entitled to at least 14 weeks (98 calendar days) of paid leave for the birth of a child through maternity leave, parental leave or a combination of both.

indicators.name: The government administers 100 percent of maternity leave benefits (1=yes; 0=no)
indicators.description: The indicator measures whether leave benefits are fully administered by a government entity, including compulsory social insurance schemes (such as social security), public funds, government-mandated private insurance or employer reimbursement of any maternity leave benefits paid directly to an employee.

indicators.name: Lifetime risk of maternal death (1 in: rate varies by country)
indicators.description: Life time risk of maternal death is the probability that a 15-year-old female will die eventually from a maternal cause assuming that current levels of fertility and mortality (including maternal mortality) do not change in the future, taking into account competing causes of death.

indicators.name: Lifetime risk of maternal death (%)
indicators.description: Life time risk of maternal death is the probability that a 15-year-old female will die eventually from a maternal cause assuming that current levels of fertility and mortality (including maternal mortality) do not change in the future, taking into account competing causes of death.

indicators.name: Maternal leave benefits (% of wages paid in covered period)
indicators.description: Maternity leave benefits refers to the total percentage of wages covered by all sources during paid maternity leave.

indicators.name: Length of paid shared parental leave (calendar days)
indicators.description: The indicator refers to parental leave that can be shared amongst the parents as they choose. Parental leave refers to leave available equally to parentsâ€”regardless of genderâ€”for the purpose of childcare immediately following maternity and paternity leave OR instead of maternity and paternity leave.

indicators.name: There is paid parental leave (1=yes; 0=no)
indicators.description: The indicator measures whether both parents are legally entitled to some form of full-time paid parental leave either shared between mother and father or as an individual entitlement that each can take regardless of the other.

indicators.name: Length of paid parental leave for mother (calendar days)
indicators.description: The indicator refers to days of parental leave reserved specifically for mothersâ€”through â€œuse-it-or-lose-itâ€ policies or mothersâ€™ quotas; or days of parental leave that employees are individually entitled to.

indicators.name: Length of paid parental leave for father (calendar days)
indicators.description: The indicator refers to days of parental leave reserved specifically for fathersâ€”that is, through â€œuse-it-or-lose-itâ€ policies or fathersâ€™ quotas; or days of parental leave that employees are individually entitled to.

indicators.name: Prevalence of current tobacco use, females (% of female adults)
indicators.description: The percentage of the female population ages 15 years and over who currently use any tobacco product (smoked and/or smokeless tobacco) on a daily or non-daily basis. Tobacco products include cigarettes, pipes, cigars, cigarillos, waterpipes (hookah, shisha), bidis, kretek, heated tobacco products, and all forms of smokeless (oral and nasal) tobacco. Tobacco products exclude e-cigarettes (which do not contain tobacco), â€œe-cigarsâ€, â€œe-hookahsâ€, JUUL and â€œe-pipesâ€. The rates are age-standardized to the WHO Standard Population.

indicators.name: Prevalence of current tobacco use, males (% of male adults)
indicators.description: The percentage of the male population ages 15 years and over who currently use any tobacco product (smoked and/or smokeless tobacco) on a daily or non-daily basis. Tobacco products include cigarettes, pipes, cigars, cigarillos, waterpipes (hookah, shisha), bidis, kretek, heated tobacco products, and all forms of smokeless (oral and nasal) tobacco. Tobacco products exclude e-cigarettes (which do not contain tobacco), â€œe-cigarsâ€, â€œe-hookahsâ€, JUUL and â€œe-pipesâ€. The rates are age-standardized to the WHO Standard Population.

indicators.name: Length of paid paternity leave (calendar days)
indicators.description: The indicator refers to leave available only to the father for the birth of a child.

indicators.name: Paid leave is available to fathers (1=yes; 0=no)
indicators.description: The indicator measures whether fathers are legally entitled to at least one day of paid leave for the birth of a child, or if the law reserves a portion of paid parental leave specifically for fathersâ€”that is, through â€œuse-it-or-lose-itâ€ policies or fathersâ€™ quotas; or if fathers are individually entitled to paid parental leave.

indicators.name: Pregnant women receiving prenatal care (%)
indicators.description: Pregnant women receiving prenatal care are the percentage of women attended at least once during pregnancy by skilled health personnel for reasons related to pregnancy.

indicators.name: Births attended by skilled health staff (% of total)
indicators.description: Births attended by skilled health staff are the percentage of deliveries attended by personnel trained to give the necessary supervision, care, and advice to women during pregnancy, labor, and the postpartum period; to conduct deliveries on their own; and to care for newborns.

indicators.name: Prevalence of underweight, weight for age, female (% of children under 5)
indicators.description: Prevalence of underweight, female, is the percentage of girls under age 5 whose weight for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. The data are based on the WHO's 2006 Child Growth Standards.

indicators.name: Prevalence of underweight, weight for age, male (% of children under 5)
indicators.description: Prevalence of underweight, male, is the percentage of boys under age 5 whose weight for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. The data are based on the WHO's 2006 Child Growth Standards.

indicators.name: Maternal mortality ratio (modeled estimate, per 100,000 live births)
indicators.description: Maternal mortality ratio is the number of women who die from pregnancy-related causes while pregnant or within 42 days of pregnancy termination per 100,000 live births. The data are estimated with a regression model using information on the proportion of maternal deaths among non-AIDS deaths in women ages 15-49, fertility, birth attendants, and GDP measured using purchasing power parities (PPPs).

indicators.name: Maternal mortality ratio (national estimate, per 100,000 live births)
indicators.description: Maternal mortality ratio is the number of women who die from pregnancy-related causes while pregnant or within 42 days of pregnancy termination per 100,000 live births.

indicators.name: Prevalence of obesity, female (% of female population ages 18+)
indicators.description: Prevalence of obesity adult is the percentage of adults ages 18 and over whose Body Mass Index (BMI) is 30 kg/mÂ² or higher. Body Mass Index (BMI) is a simple index of weight-for-height, or the weight in kilograms divided by the square of the height in meters.

indicators.name: Prevalence of obesity, male (% of male population ages 18+)
indicators.description: Prevalence of obesity adult is the percentage of adults ages 18 and over whose Body Mass Index (BMI) is 30 kg/mÂ² or higher. Body Mass Index (BMI) is a simple index of weight-for-height, or the weight in kilograms divided by the square of the height in meters.

indicators.name: Child employment in agriculture, female (% of female economically active children ages 7-14)
indicators.description: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories of the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC). Agriculture corresponds to division 1 (ISIC revision 2), categories A and B (ISIC revision 3), or category A (ISIC revision 4) and includes hunting, forestry, and fishing. Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.

indicators.name: Child employment in agriculture, male (% of male economically active children ages 7-14)
indicators.description: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories of the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC). Agriculture corresponds to division 1 (ISIC revision 2), categories A and B (ISIC revision 3), or category A (ISIC revision 4) and includes hunting, forestry, and fishing. Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.

indicators.name: Employment in agriculture, female (% of female employment) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Employment is defined as persons of working age who were engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit, whether at work during the reference period or not at work due to temporary absence from a job, or to working-time arrangement. The agriculture sector consists of activities in agriculture, hunting, forestry and fishing, in accordance with division 1 (ISIC 2) or categories A-B (ISIC 3) or category A (ISIC 4).

indicators.name: Employment in agriculture, male (% of male employment) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Employment is defined as persons of working age who were engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit, whether at work during the reference period or not at work due to temporary absence from a job, or to working-time arrangement. The agriculture sector consists of activities in agriculture, hunting, forestry and fishing, in accordance with division 1 (ISIC 2) or categories A-B (ISIC 3) or category A (ISIC 4).

indicators.name: Employment to population ratio, ages 15-24, female (%) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Employment to population ratio is the proportion of a country's population that is employed. Employment is defined as persons of working age who, during a short reference period, were engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit, whether at work during the reference period (i.e. who worked in a job for at least one hour) or not at work due to temporary absence from a job, or to working-time arrangements. Ages 15-24 are generally considered the youth population.

indicators.name: Employment to population ratio, ages 15-24, male (%) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Employment to population ratio is the proportion of a country's population that is employed. Employment is defined as persons of working age who, during a short reference period, were engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit, whether at work during the reference period (i.e. who worked in a job for at least one hour) or not at work due to temporary absence from a job, or to working-time arrangements. Ages 15-24 are generally considered the youth population.

indicators.name: Share of women in wage employment in the nonagricultural sector (% of total nonagricultural employment)
indicators.description: Share of women in wage employment in the nonagricultural sector is the share of female workers in wage employment in the nonagricultural sector (industry and services), expressed as a percentage of total employment in the nonagricultural sector. Industry includes mining and quarrying (including oil production), manufacturing, construction, electricity, gas, and water, corresponding to divisions 2-5 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories C-F (ISIC revision 3). Services include wholesale and retail trade and restaurants and hotels; transport, storage, and communications; financing, insurance, real estate, and business services; and community, social, and personal services-corresponding to divisions 6-9 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories G-Q (ISIC revision 3).

indicators.name: Employers, female (% of female employment) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Employers are those workers who, working on their own account or with one or a few partners, hold the type of jobs defined as a "self-employment jobs" i.e. jobs where the remuneration is directly dependent upon the profits derived from the goods and services produced), and, in this capacity, have engaged, on a continuous basis, one or more persons to work for them as employee(s).

indicators.name: Employers, male (% of male employment) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Employers are those workers who, working on their own account or with one or a few partners, hold the type of jobs defined as a "self-employment jobs" i.e. jobs where the remuneration is directly dependent upon the profits derived from the goods and services produced), and, in this capacity, have engaged, on a continuous basis, one or more persons to work for them as employee(s).

indicators.name: Own-account workers, female (% of female employment) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Own-account workers are workers who, working on their own account or with one or more more partners, hold the types of jobs defined as "self-employment jobs" and have not engaged on a continuous basis any employees to work for them. Own account workers are a subcategory of "self-employed".

indicators.name: Own-account workers, male (% of male employment) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Own-account workers are workers who, working on their own account or with one or more more partners, hold the types of jobs defined as "self-employment jobs" and have not engaged on a continuous basis any employees to work for them. Own account workers are a subcategory of "self-employed".

indicators.name: Self-employed, female (% of female employment) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Self-employed workers are those workers who, working on their own account or with one or a few partners or in cooperative, hold the type of jobs defined as a "self-employment jobs." i.e. jobs where the remuneration is directly dependent upon the profits derived from the goods and services produced. Self-employed workers include four sub-categories of employers, own-account workers, members of producers' cooperatives, and contributing family workers.

indicators.name: Self-employed, male (% of male employment) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Self-employed workers are those workers who, working on their own account or with one or a few partners or in cooperative, hold the type of jobs defined as a "self-employment jobs." i.e. jobs where the remuneration is directly dependent upon the profits derived from the goods and services produced. Self-employed workers include four sub-categories of employers, own-account workers, members of producers' cooperatives, and contributing family workers.

indicators.name: Employment to population ratio, 15+, female (%) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Employment to population ratio is the proportion of a country's population that is employed. Employment is defined as persons of working age who, during a short reference period, were engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit, whether at work during the reference period (i.e. who worked in a job for at least one hour) or not at work due to temporary absence from a job, or to working-time arrangements. Ages 15 and older are generally considered the working-age population.

indicators.name: Employment to population ratio, 15+, male (%) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Employment to population ratio is the proportion of a country's population that is employed. Employment is defined as persons of working age who, during a short reference period, were engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit, whether at work during the reference period (i.e. who worked in a job for at least one hour) or not at work due to temporary absence from a job, or to working-time arrangements. Ages 15 and older are generally considered the working-age population.

indicators.name: Time-related underemployment, female (% of employment)
indicators.description: Time-related underemployment refers to all persons in employment who (i) wanted to work additional hours, (ii) had worked less than a specified hours threshold (working time in all jobs), and (iii) were available to work additional hours given an opportunity for more work.

indicators.name: Time-related underemployment, male (% of employment)
indicators.description: Time-related underemployment refers to all persons in employment who (i) wanted to work additional hours, (ii) had worked less than a specified hours threshold (working time in all jobs), and (iii) were available to work additional hours given an opportunity for more work.

indicators.name: Vulnerable employment, female (% of female employment) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Vulnerable employment is contributing family workers and own-account workers as a percentage of total employment.

indicators.name: Vulnerable employment, male (% of male employment) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Vulnerable employment is contributing family workers and own-account workers as a percentage of total employment.

indicators.name: Wage and salaried workers, female (% of female employment) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Wage and salaried workers (employees) are those workers who hold the type of jobs defined as "paid employment jobs," where the incumbents hold explicit (written or oral) or implicit employment contracts that give them a basic remuneration that is not directly dependent upon the revenue of the unit for which they work.

indicators.name: Wage and salaried workers, male (% of male employment) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Wage and salaried workers (employees) are those workers who hold the type of jobs defined as "paid employment jobs," where the incumbents hold explicit (written or oral) or implicit employment contracts that give them a basic remuneration that is not directly dependent upon the revenue of the unit for which they work.

indicators.name: Contributing family workers, female (% of female employment) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Contributing family workers are those workers who hold "self-employment jobs" as own-account workers in a market-oriented establishment operated by a related person living in the same household.

indicators.name: Contributing family workers, male (% of male employment) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Contributing family workers are those workers who hold "self-employment jobs" as own-account workers in a market-oriented establishment operated by a related person living in the same household.

indicators.name: Employment in industry, female (% of female employment) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Employment is defined as persons of working age who were engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit, whether at work during the reference period or not at work due to temporary absence from a job, or to working-time arrangement. The industry sector consists of mining and quarrying, manufacturing, construction, and public utilities (electricity, gas, and water), in accordance with divisions 2-5 (ISIC 2) or categories C-F (ISIC 3) or categories B-F (ISIC 4).

indicators.name: Employment in industry, male (% of male employment) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Employment is defined as persons of working age who were engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit, whether at work during the reference period or not at work due to temporary absence from a job, or to working-time arrangement. The industry sector consists of mining and quarrying, manufacturing, construction, and public utilities (electricity, gas, and water), in accordance with divisions 2-5 (ISIC 2) or categories C-F (ISIC 3) or categories B-F (ISIC 4).

indicators.name: Child employment in manufacturing, female (% of female economically active children ages 7-14)
indicators.description: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories of the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC). Manufacturing corresponds to division 3 (ISIC revision 2), category D (ISIC revision 3), or category C (ISIC revision 4). Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.

indicators.name: Child employment in manufacturing, male (% of male economically active children ages 7-14)
indicators.description: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories of the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC). Manufacturing corresponds to division 3 (ISIC revision 2), category D (ISIC revision 3), or category C (ISIC revision 4). Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.

indicators.name: Ratio of female to male wages in manufacturing (%)
indicators.description: Ratio of female to male wages in manufacturing refers to female to male wages and salaries in manufacturing.

indicators.name: Child employment in services, female (% of female economically active children ages 7-14)
indicators.description: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories of the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC). Services correspond to divisions 6-9 (ISIC revision 2), categories G-P (ISIC revision 3), or categories G-U (ISIC revision 4). Services include wholesale and retail trade, hotels and restaurants, transport, financial intermediation, real estate, public administration, education, health and social work, other community services, and private household activity. Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.

indicators.name: Child employment in services, male (% of male economically active children ages 7-14)
indicators.description: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories of the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC). Services correspond to divisions 6-9 (ISIC revision 2), categories G-P (ISIC revision 3), or categories G-U (ISIC revision 4). Services include wholesale and retail trade, hotels and restaurants, transport, financial intermediation, real estate, public administration, education, health and social work, other community services, and private household activity. Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.

indicators.name: Employment in services, female (% of female employment) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Employment is defined as persons of working age who were engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit, whether at work during the reference period or not at work due to temporary absence from a job, or to working-time arrangement. The services sector consists of wholesale and retail trade and restaurants and hotels; transport, storage, and communications; financing, insurance, real estate, and business services; and community, social, and personal services, in accordance with divisions 6-9 (ISIC 2) or categories G-Q (ISIC 3) or categories G-U (ISIC 4).

indicators.name: Employment in services, male (% of male employment) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Employment is defined as persons of working age who were engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit, whether at work during the reference period or not at work due to temporary absence from a job, or to working-time arrangement. The services sector consists of wholesale and retail trade and restaurants and hotels; transport, storage, and communications; financing, insurance, real estate, and business services; and community, social, and personal services, in accordance with divisions 6-9 (ISIC 2) or categories G-Q (ISIC 3) or categories G-U (ISIC 4).

indicators.name: Children in employment, female (% of female children ages 7-14)
indicators.description: Children in employment refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.

indicators.name: Children in employment, male (% of male children ages 7-14)
indicators.description: Children in employment refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.

indicators.name: Children in employment, study and work, female (% of female children in employment, ages 7-14)
indicators.description: Children in employment refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey. Study and work refer to children attending school in combination with economic activity.

indicators.name: Children in employment, study and work, male (% of male children in employment, ages 7-14)
indicators.description: Children in employment refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey. Study and work refer to children attending school in combination with economic activity.

indicators.name: Children in employment, work only, female (% of female children in employment, ages 7-14)
indicators.description: Children in employment refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey. Work only refers to children involved in economic activity and not attending school.

indicators.name: Children in employment, work only, male (% of male children in employment, ages 7-14)
indicators.description: Children in employment refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey. Work only refers to children involved in economic activity and not attending school.

indicators.name: Labor force participation rate, female (% of female population ages 15+) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Labor force participation rate is the proportion of the population ages 15 and older that is economically active: all people who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period.

indicators.name: Labor force participation rate, male (% of male population ages 15+) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Labor force participation rate is the proportion of the population ages 15 and older that is economically active: all people who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period.

indicators.name: Part time employment, female (% of total female employment)
indicators.description: Part time employment refers to regular employment in which working time is substantially less than normal. Definitions of part time employment differ by country.

indicators.name: Part time employment, male (% of total male employment)
indicators.description: Part time employment refers to regular employment in which working time is substantially less than normal. Definitions of part time employment differ by country.

indicators.name: Part time employment, female (% of total part time employment)
indicators.description: Part time employment refers to regular employment in which working time is substantially less than normal. Definitions of part time employment differ by country.

indicators.name: Labor force with primary education, female (% of female labor force)
indicators.description: Female labor force with primary education is the share of the female labor force that attained or completed primary education as the highest level of education.

indicators.name: Labor force with primary education, male (% of male labor force)
indicators.description: Male labor force with primary education is the share of the male labor force that attained or completed primary education as the highest level of education.

indicators.name: Labor force with secondary education, female (% of female labor force)
indicators.description: Female labor force with secondary education is the share of the female labor force that attained or completed secondary education as the highest level of education.

indicators.name: Labor force with secondary education, male (% of male labor force)
indicators.description: Male labor force with secondary education is the share of the male labor force that attained or completed secondary education as the highest level of education.

indicators.name: Labor force with tertiary education, female (% of female labor force)
indicators.description: Female labor force with tertiary education is the share of the female labor force that attained or completed tertiary education as the highest level of education.

indicators.name: Labor force with tertiary education, male (% of male labor force)
indicators.description: Male labor force with tertiary education is the share of the male labor force that attained or completed tertiary education as the highest level of education.

indicators.name: Labor force, female
indicators.description: Female labor force comprises women ages 15 and older who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period. It includes people who are currently employed and people who are unemployed but seeking work as well as first-time job-seekers. Not everyone who works is included, however. Unpaid workers, family workers, and students are often omitted, and some countries do not count members of the armed forces. Labor force size tends to vary during the year as seasonal workers enter and leave.

indicators.name: Labor force, female (% of total labor force)
indicators.description: Female labor force as a percentage of the total show the extent to which women are active in the labor force. Labor force comprises people ages 15 and older who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period.

indicators.name: Unemployment, youth female (% of female labor force ages 15-24) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Youth unemployment refers to the share of the labor force ages 15-24 without work but available for and seeking employment.

indicators.name: Ratio of female to male youth unemployment rate (%) (national estimate)
indicators.description: Ratio of female to male youth unemployment is the percentage of female to male youth unemployment rates.

indicators.name: Ratio of female to male youth unemployment rate (% ages 15-24) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Ratio of female to male youth unemployment is the percentage of female to male youth unemployment rates.

indicators.name: Unemployment, youth male (% of male labor force ages 15-24) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Youth unemployment refers to the share of the labor force ages 15-24 without work but available for and seeking employment.

indicators.name: Long-term unemployment, female (% of female unemployment)
indicators.description: Long-term unemployment refers to the number of people with continuous periods of unemployment extending for a year or longer, expressed as a percentage of the total unemployed.

indicators.name: Long-term unemployment, male (% of male unemployment)
indicators.description: Long-term unemployment refers to the number of people with continuous periods of unemployment extending for a year or longer, expressed as a percentage of the total unemployed.

indicators.name: Unemployment with primary education, female (% of female unemployment)
indicators.description: Female unemployment with primary education is the share of the female unemployed who attained or completed primary education as the highest level.

indicators.name: Unemployment with primary education, male (% of male unemployment)
indicators.description: Male unemployment with primary education is the share of the male unemployed who attained or completed primary education as the highest level.

indicators.name: Unemployment with secondary education, female (% of female unemployment)
indicators.description: Female unemployment with secondary education is the share of the female unemployed who attained or completed secondary education as the highest level.

indicators.name: Unemployment with secondary education, male (% of male unemployment)
indicators.description: Male unemployment with secondary education is the share of the male unemployed who attained or completed secondary education as the highest level.

indicators.name: Unemployment with tertiary education, female (% of female unemployment)
indicators.description: Female unemployment with tertiary education is the share of the female unemployed who attained or completed tertiary education as the highest level.

indicators.name: Unemployment with tertiary education, male (% of male unemployment)
indicators.description: Male unemployment with tertiary education is the share of the male unemployed who attained or completed tertiary education as the highest level.

indicators.name: Unemployment, female (% of female labor force) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Unemployment refers to the share of the labor force that is without work but available for and seeking employment.

indicators.name: Unemployment, male (% of male labor force) (modeled ILO estimate)
indicators.description: Unemployment refers to the share of the labor force that is without work but available for and seeking employment.

indicators.name: Adolescent fertility rate (births per 1,000 women ages 15-19)
indicators.description: Adolescent fertility rate is the number of births per 1,000 women ages 15-19.

indicators.name: Mortality rate, adult, female (per 1,000 female adults)
indicators.description: Adult mortality rate, female, is the probability of dying between the ages of 15 and 60--that is, the probability of a 15-year-old female dying before reaching age 60, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of the specified year between those ages.

indicators.name: Mortality rate, adult, male (per 1,000 male adults)
indicators.description: Adult mortality rate, male, is the probability of dying between the ages of 15 and 60--that is, the probability of a 15-year-old male dying before reaching age 60, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of the specified year between those ages.

indicators.name: Contraceptive prevalence, any method (% of married women ages 15-49)
indicators.description: Contraceptive prevalence, any method is the percentage of married women ages 15-49 who are practicing, or whose sexual partners are practicing, any method of contraception (modern or traditional). Modern methods of contraception include female and male sterilization, oral hormonal pills, the intra-uterine device (IUD), the male condom, injectables, the implant (including Norplant), vaginal barrier methods, the female condom and emergency contraception. Traditional methods of contraception include rhythm (e.g., fertility awareness based methods, periodic abstinence), withdrawal and other traditional methods.

indicators.name: Life expectancy at birth, female (years)
indicators.description: Life expectancy at birth indicates the number of years a newborn infant would live if prevailing patterns of mortality at the time of its birth were to stay the same throughout its life.

indicators.name: Life expectancy at birth, male (years)
indicators.description: Life expectancy at birth indicates the number of years a newborn infant would live if prevailing patterns of mortality at the time of its birth were to stay the same throughout its life.

indicators.name: Life expectancy at age 60, female (years)
indicators.description: Life expectancy at age 60, female is the average number of years that a female at age 60 would live if prevailing patterns of mortality at the time of age 60 were to stay the same throughout her life.

indicators.name: Life expectancy at age 60, male (years)
indicators.description: Life expectancy at age 60, male is the average number of years that a male at age 60 would live if prevailing patterns of mortality at the time of age 60 were to stay the same throughout his life.

indicators.name: Age at first marriage, female
indicators.description: Mean age at marriage, female shows the average length of single life expressed in years among those females who marry before age 50. It is a synthetic indicator calculated from marital status categories of men and women aged 15 to 54 at the census or survey date.

indicators.name: Age at first marriage, male
indicators.description: Mean age at marriage, male shows the average length of single life expressed in years among those males who marry before age 50. It is a synthetic indicator calculated from marital status categories of men and women aged 15 to 54 at the census or survey date.

indicators.name: Fertility rate, total (births per woman)
indicators.description: Total fertility rate represents the number of children that would be born to a woman if she were to live to the end of her childbearing years and bear children in accordance with age-specific fertility rates of the specified year.

indicators.name: Survival to age 65, female (% of cohort)
indicators.description: Survival to age 65 refers to the percentage of a cohort of newborn infants that would survive to age 65, if subject to age specific mortality rates of the specified year.

indicators.name: Survival to age 65, male (% of cohort)
indicators.description: Survival to age 65 refers to the percentage of a cohort of newborn infants that would survive to age 65, if subject to age specific mortality rates of the specified year.

indicators.name: Wanted fertility rate (births per woman)
indicators.description: Wanted fertility rate is an estimate of what the total fertility rate would be if all unwanted births were avoided.

indicators.name: Female headed households (% of households with a female head)
indicators.description: Female headed households shows the percentage of households with a female head.

indicators.name: Women who were first married by age 15 (% of women ages 20-24)
indicators.description: Women who were first married by age 15 refers to the percentage of women ages 20-24 who were first married by age 15.

indicators.name: Women who were first married by age 18 (% of women ages 20-24)
indicators.description: Women who were first married by age 18 refers to the percentage of women ages 20-24 who were first married by age 18.

indicators.name: Teenage mothers (% of women ages 15-19 who have had children or are currently pregnant)
indicators.description: Teenage mothers are the percentage of women ages 15-19 who already have children or are currently pregnant.

indicators.name: Age population, age 00, female, interpolated
indicators.description: Age population, female refers to female population at the specified age level. The geographical areas included in the data are the same as the data source.

indicators.name: Age population, age 00, male, interpolated
indicators.description: Age population, male refers to male population at the specified age level. The geographical areas included in the data are the same as the data source.

indicators.name: Age population, age 01, female, interpolated
indicators.description: Age population, female refers to female population at the specified age level. The geographical areas included in the data are the same as the data source.

indicators.name: Age population, age 01, male, interpolated
indicators.description: Age population, male refers to male population at the specified age level. The geographical areas included in the data are the same as the data source.

indicators.name: Age population, age 02, female, interpolated
indicators.description: Age population, female refers to female population at the specified age level. The geographical areas included in the data are the same as the data source.

indicators.name: Age population, age 02, male, interpolated
indicators.description: Age population, male refers to male population at the specified age level. The geographical areas included in the data are the same as the data source.

indicators.name: Age population, age 03, female, interpolated
indicators.description: Age population, female refers to female population at the specified age level. The geographical areas included in the data are the same as the data source.

indicators.name: Age population, age 03, male, interpolated
indicators.description: Age population, male refers to male population at the specified age level. The geographical areas included in the data are the same as the data source.

indicators.name: Age population, age 04, female, interpolated
indicators.description: Age population, female refers to female population at the specified age level. The geographical areas included in the data are the same as the data source.

indicators.name: Age population, age 04, male, interpolated
indicators.description: Age population, male refers to male population at the specified age level. The geographical areas included in the data are the same as the data source.

indicators.name: Age population, age 05, female, interpolated
indicators.description: Age population, female refers to female population at the specified age level. The geographical areas included in the data are the same as the data source.

indicators.name: Age population, age 05, male, interpolated
indicators.description: Age population, male refers to male population at the specified age level. The geographical areas included in the data are the same as the data source.

indicators.name: Rural population, female (% of total)
indicators.description: Female rural population is the percentage of females who live in rural areas to total population.

indicators.name: Rural population, male (% of total)
indicators.description: Male rural population is the percentage males who live in rural areas to total population.

indicators.name: Urban population, female (% of total)
indicators.description: Female urban population is the percentage of females who live in urban areas to total population.

indicators.name: Urban population, male (% of total)
indicators.description: Male urban population is the percentage of males who live in urban areas to total population.

indicators.name: Account at a financial institution, male (% age 15+)
indicators.description: Account at a financial institution denotes the percentage of respondents who report having an account (by themselves or together with someone else) at a bank or another type of financial institution.

indicators.name: Account at a financial institution, female (% age 15+)
indicators.description: Account at a financial institution denotes the percentage of respondents who report having an account (by themselves or together with someone else) at a bank or another type of financial institution.

indicators.name: Mobile account, male (% age 15+)
indicators.description: Mobile account denotes the percentage of respondents who report personally using a mobile phone to pay bills or to send or receive money through a GSM Association (GSMA) Mobile Money for the Unbanked (MMU) service in the past 12 months; or receiving wages, government transfers, or payments for agricultural products through a mobile phone in the past 12 months.

indicators.name: Mobile account, female (% age 15+)
indicators.description: Mobile account denotes the percentage of respondents who report personally using a mobile phone to pay bills or to send or receive money through a GSM Association (GSMA) Mobile Money for the Unbanked (MMU) service in the past 12 months; or receiving wages, government transfers, or payments for agricultural products through a mobile phone in the past 12 months.

indicators.name: Total bilateral ODA commitments (current US$)
indicators.description: Bilateral official development assistance (ODA) commitments are firm obligations, expressed in writing and backed by the necessary funds, undertaken by official bilateral donors to provide specified assistance to a recipient country or a multilateral organization. Bilateral commitments are recorded in the full amount of expected transfer, irrespective of the time required for completing disbursements. OECD DAC.

indicators.name: Total bilateral sector allocable ODA commitments (current US$)
indicators.description: Bilateral official development assistance (ODA) commitments are firm obligations, expressed in writing and backed by the necessary funds, undertaken by official bilateral donors to provide specified assistance to a recipient country or a multilateral organization. Bilateral commitments are recorded in the full amount of expected transfer, irrespective of the time required for completing disbursements. Total sector-allocable aid is the sum of aid that can be assigned to specific sectors or multisector activities. OECD DAC.

indicators.name: Bilateral, sector-allocable ODA to basic social services (current US$)
indicators.description: Bilateral official development assistance (ODA) commitments are firm obligations, expressed in writing and backed by the necessary funds, undertaken by official bilateral donors to provide specified assistance to a recipient country or a multilateral organization. Bilateral commitments are recorded in the full amount of expected transfer, irrespective of the time required for completing disbursements. Total sector-allocable aid is the sum of aid that can be assigned to specific sectors or multisector activities. Basic social services consists of, primary education, basic life skills for youth and adults and early childhood education, basic health care, basic health infrastructure, basic nutrition, infectious disease control, health education and health personnel development, population policy and administrative management, reproductive health care, family planning, sexually transmitted disease (STD) control including HIV/AIDS, personnel development (population & reproductive health), basic drinking water supply and basic sanitation, and multi-sector aid for basic social services. OECD DAC.

indicators.name: Bilateral, sector-allocable ODA to basic social services (% of bilateral ODA commitments)
indicators.description: Bilateral official development assistance (ODA) commitments are firm obligations, expressed in writing and backed by the necessary funds, undertaken by official bilateral donors to provide specified assistance to a recipient country or a multilateral organization. Bilateral commitments are recorded in the full amount of expected transfer, irrespective of the time required for completing disbursements. Total sector-allocable aid is the sum of aid that can be assigned to specific sectors or multisector activities. Basic social services consists of, primary education, basic life skills for youth and adults and early childhood education, basic health care, basic health infrastructure, basic nutrition, infectious disease control, health education and health personnel development, population policy and administrative management, reproductive health care, family planning, sexually transmitted disease (STD) control including HIV/AIDS, personnel development (population & reproductive health), basic drinking water supply and basic sanitation, and multi-sector aid for basic social services.

indicators.name: Net ODA provided, to the least developed countries (current US$)
indicators.description: Net Official development assistance (ODA) comprises grants or loans to developing countries and territories on the OECD/DAC list of aid recipients that are undertaken by the official sector with promotion of economic development and welfare as the main objective and at concessional financial terms. The list of least developed countries (LDCs) has been agreed by the General Assembly, on the recommendation of the Committee for Development Policy, Economic and Social Council.

indicators.name: Net ODA provided to the least developed countries (% of GNI)
indicators.description: Net Official development assistance (ODA) comprises grants or loans to developing countries and territories on the OECD/DAC list of aid recipients that are undertaken by the official sector with promotion of economic development and welfare as the main objective and at concessional financial terms. The list of least developed countries (LDCs) has been agreed by the General Assembly, on the recommendation of the Committee for Development Policy, Economic and Social Council. Series is shown as a share of donors' GNI.

indicators.name: Net ODA provided, total (current US$)
indicators.description: Net Official development assistance (ODA) comprises grants or loans to developing countries and territories on the OECD/DAC list of aid recipients that are undertaken by the official sector with promotion of economic development and welfare as the main objective and at concessional financial terms.

indicators.name: Net ODA provided, total (% of GNI)
indicators.description: Net Official development assistance (ODA) comprises grants or loans to developing countries and territories on the OECD/DAC list of aid recipients that are undertaken by the official sector with promotion of economic development and welfare as the main objective and at concessional financial terms. It is shown as a share of donors' GNI.

indicators.name: Net ODA provided, total (constant 2021 US$)
indicators.description: Net Official development assistance (ODA) comprises grants or loans to developing countries and territories on the OECD/DAC list of aid recipients that are undertaken by the official sector with promotion of economic development and welfare as the main objective and at concessional financial terms. Data are in constant 2021 U.S. dollars.

indicators.name: Bilateral ODA commitments that is untied (current US$)
indicators.description: Bilateral official development assistance (ODA) commitments are firm obligations, expressed in writing and backed by the necessary funds, undertaken by official bilateral donors to provide specified assistance to a recipient country or a multilateral organization. Bilateral commitments are recorded in the full amount of expected transfer, irrespective of the time required for completing disbursements. Untied bilateral official development assistance is assistance from country to country for which the associated goods and services may be fully and freely procured in substantially all countries. OECD DAC.

indicators.name: Bilateral ODA commitments that is untied (% of bilateral ODA commitments)
indicators.description: Bilateral official development assistance (ODA) commitments are firm obligations, expressed in writing and backed by the necessary funds, undertaken by official bilateral donors to provide specified assistance to a recipient country or a multilateral organization. Bilateral commitments are recorded in the full amount of expected transfer, irrespective of the time required for completing disbursements. Untied bilateral official development assistance is assistance from country to country for which the associated goods and services may be fully and freely procured in substantially all countries.

indicators.name: Debt relief committed under HIPC initiative, cumulative US$ in end-2012 NPV terms
indicators.description: Debt relief is committed as of the decision point (assuming full participation of creditors) under the enhanced HIPC Initiative. It is calculated as the amount needed to bring the net present value (NPV) of the country's debt level to the thresholds established by the HIPC Initiative (150 percent of exports or in certain cases 250 percent of fiscal revenues). Topping-up assistance and assistance provided under the original HIPC Initiative were committed in net present value terms as of the decision point and are converted to end-2012 terms.

indicators.name: Debt relief delivered in full under MDRI initiative, cumulative US$ in end-2012 NPV terms
indicators.description: Debt relief delivered in full under MDRI initiative is the net present value of debt relief from International Development Association, International Monetary Fund, African Development Fund, and Inter-American Development Bank and delivered to countries having reached the HIPC completion point converted to end-2012 terms.

indicators.name: Status under enhanced HIPC initiative
indicators.description: Indicator shows the status of heavily indebted poor countries country under the enhanced HIPC initiative. Heavily indebted poor countries reach HIPC decision point if they have a track record of macroeconomic stability, have prepared an Interim Poverty Reduction Strategy through a participatory process, and have cleared or reached an agreement on a process to clear, the outstanding arrears to multilateral creditors. The amount of debt relief necessary to bring countriesâ€™ debt indicators to HIPC thresholds is calculated, and countries begin receiving debt relief. Heavily indebted poor countries reach HIPC completion point if they maintain macroeconomic stability under a Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF) supported program, carry out key structural and social reforms agreed on at the decision point, and implement satisfactorily Poverty Reduction Strategy for one year. Debt relief is then provided irrevocably by the countryâ€™s creditors.

indicators.name: Debt relief committed under HIPC and MDRI initiatives, cumulative US$ in end-2012 NPV terms
indicators.description: Debt relief is committed as of the decision point (assuming full participation of creditors) under the enhanced HIPC Initiative. It is calculated as the amount needed to bring the net present value (NPV) of the country's debt level to the thresholds established by the HIPC Initiative (150 percent of exports or in certain cases 250 percent of fiscal revenues). Topping-up assistance and assistance provided under the original HIPC Initiative were committed in net present value terms as of the decision point and are converted to end-2012 terms. Debt relief delivered in full under MDRI initiative is the net present value of debt relief from International Development Association, International Monetary Fund, African Development Fund, and Inter-American Development Bank and delivered to countries having reached the HIPC completion point converted to end-2012 terms.

indicators.name: Agricultural support estimate (% of GDP)
indicators.description: Agriculture support is the annual monetary value of all gross transfers from taxpayers and consumers, both domestic and foreign (in the form of subsidies arising from policy measures that support agriculture), net of the associated budgetary receipts, regardless of their objectives and impacts on farm production and income, or consumption of farm products.

indicators.name: Malaria prevention, use of bed nets (% of under-5 children in the poorest quintile)
indicators.description: Use of bed nets by children in the poorest quintile refers to the percentage of children under age five in the poorest quintile who slept under an any type of mosquito bednet to prevent malaria.

indicators.name: Malaria prevention, use of bed nets (% of under-5 children in the richest quintile)
indicators.description: Use of bed nets by children in the richest quintile refers to the percentage of children under age five in the richest quintile who slept under an any type of mosquito bednet to prevent malaria.

indicators.name: Goods (excluding arms) admitted free of tariffs from developing countries (% total merchandise imports excluding arms)
indicators.description: It is the proportion of duty free imports (excluding arms) into developed countries from developing and least developed countries. For the purpose of calculating this indicator, Japan in Asia, Canada and the United States in North America, Australia and New Zealand in Oceania and Iceland, Norway, Switzerland and the EU (25 countries included since 2004) in Europe are considered â€œdevelopedâ€ regions or areas, following the common accepted practice used for MDG indicators. Developing countries are those not listed as developed or transition countries. The list of least developed countries (LDCs) has been agreed by the General Assembly, on the recommendation of the Committee for Development Policy, Economic and Social Council.

indicators.name: Goods (excluding arms) admitted free of tariffs from least developed countries (% total merchandise imports excluding arms)
indicators.description: It is the proportion of duty free imports (excluding arms) into developed countries from developing and least developed countries. For the purpose of calculating this indicator, Japan in Asia, Canada and the United States in North America, Australia and New Zealand in Oceania and Iceland, Norway, Switzerland and the EU (25 countries included since 2004) in Europe are considered â€œdevelopedâ€ regions or areas, following the common accepted practice used for MDG indicators. Developing countries are those not listed as developed or transition countries. The list of least developed countries (LDCs) has been agreed by the General Assembly, on the recommendation of the Committee for Development Policy, Economic and Social Council.

indicators.name: Average tariffs imposed by developed countries on agricultural products from developing countries (%)
indicators.description: It is the average tariffs imposed by developed countries on subsets of selected items (agricultural products, textile and clothing exports) that are deemed to be of interest to developing countries. For the purpose of calculating this indicator, Japan in Asia, Canada and the United States in North America, Australia and New Zealand in Oceania and Iceland, Norway, Switzerland and the EU (25 countries included since 2004) in Europe are considered â€œdevelopedâ€ regions or areas, following the common accepted practice used for MDG indicators. Developing countries are those not listed as developed or transition countries. The list of least developed countries (LDCs) has been agreed by the General Assembly, on the recommendation of the Committee for Development Policy, Economic and Social Council. Agricultural, clothing and textile groups follow the definition in WTO agreements based on the Harmonized System 1992, transposed to current versions by WTO Secretariat. Agricultural products correspond to Harmonized System 1992, chapters 01 to 24 less fish and fish products (chap. 03); in addition to parts of chapters 29, 33, 35, 38, 41, 43, 50 to 53. Textile is mainly covered in chapters 50 to 60. The bulk of clothing products are found in chapters 61-63.

indicators.name: Average tariffs imposed by developed countries on agricultural products from least developed countries (%)
indicators.description: It is the average tariffs imposed by developed countries on subsets of selected items (agricultural products, textile and clothing exports) that are deemed to be of interest to developing countries. For the purpose of calculating this indicator, Japan in Asia, Canada and the United States in North America, Australia and New Zealand in Oceania and Iceland, Norway, Switzerland and the EU (25 countries included since 2004) in Europe are considered â€œdevelopedâ€ regions or areas, following the common accepted practice used for MDG indicators. Developing countries are those not listed as developed or transition countries. The list of least developed countries (LDCs) has been agreed by the General Assembly, on the recommendation of the Committee for Development Policy, Economic and Social Council. Agricultural, clothing and textile groups follow the definition in WTO agreements based on the Harmonized System 1992, transposed to current versions by WTO Secretariat. Agricultural products correspond to Harmonized System 1992, chapters 01 to 24 less fish and fish products (chap. 03); in addition to parts of chapters 29, 33, 35, 38, 41, 43, 50 to 53. Textile is mainly covered in chapters 50 to 60. The bulk of clothing products are found in chapters 61-63.

indicators.name: Average tariffs imposed by developed countries on clothing products from developing countries (%)
indicators.description: It is the average tariffs imposed by developed countries on subsets of selected items (agricultural products, textile and clothing exports) that are deemed to be of interest to developing countries. For the purpose of calculating this indicator, Japan in Asia, Canada and the United States in North America, Australia and New Zealand in Oceania and Iceland, Norway, Switzerland and the EU (25 countries included since 2004) in Europe are considered â€œdevelopedâ€ regions or areas, following the common accepted practice used for MDG indicators. Developing countries are those not listed as developed or transition countries. The list of least developed countries (LDCs) has been agreed by the General Assembly, on the recommendation of the Committee for Development Policy, Economic and Social Council. Agricultural, clothing and textile groups follow the definition in WTO agreements based on the Harmonized System 1992, transposed to current versions by WTO Secretariat. Agricultural products correspond to Harmonized System 1992, chapters 01 to 24 less fish and fish products (chap. 03); in addition to parts of chapters 29, 33, 35, 38, 41, 43, 50 to 53. Textile is mainly covered in chapters 50 to 60. The bulk of clothing products are found in chapters 61-63.

indicators.name: Average tariffs imposed by developed countries on clothing products from least developed countries (%)
indicators.description: It is the average tariffs imposed by developed countries on subsets of selected items (agricultural products, textile and clothing exports) that are deemed to be of interest to developing countries. For the purpose of calculating this indicator, Japan in Asia, Canada and the United States in North America, Australia and New Zealand in Oceania and Iceland, Norway, Switzerland and the EU (25 countries included since 2004) in Europe are considered â€œdevelopedâ€ regions or areas, following the common accepted practice used for MDG indicators. Agricultural products correspond to Harmonized System 1992, chapters 01 to 24 less fish and fish products (chap. 03); in addition to parts of chapters 29, 33, 35, 38, 41, 43, 50 to 53. Textile is mainly covered in chapters 50 to 60. The bulk of clothing products are found in chapters 61-63.

indicators.name: Average tariffs imposed by developed countries on textile products from developing countries (%)
indicators.description: It is the average tariffs imposed by developed countries on subsets of selected items (agricultural products, textile and clothing exports) that are deemed to be of interest to developing countries. For the purpose of calculating this indicator, Japan in Asia, Canada and the United States in North America, Australia and New Zealand in Oceania and Iceland, Norway, Switzerland and the EU (25 countries included since 2004) in Europe are considered â€œdevelopedâ€ regions or areas, following the common accepted practice used for MDG indicators.
